questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. She says that the symptoms started after completing a half-marathon. Shortly after the headache started, she also had weakness of the right upper extremity and sudden loss of vision in her left eye, both of which subsided after a few minutes. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. On arrival, she is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left eyelid and a constricted left pupil. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal bilaterally. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck shows an absent flow in the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oxygen is the first-line treatment for cluster headaches. Although cluster headaches can present with ptosis and headache, they classically occur as recurrent attacks (up to 8 times per day) of pain in either an orbital or temporal distribution. Additionally, pain in cluster headaches typically does not involve the neck, nor do they cause cerebrovascular accidents such as TIAs.

B) INCORRECT:

Sumatriptan is commonly used to treat migraines. A migraine aura may present with neurologic symptoms (e.g., extremity weakness and visual loss) that classically precede a migraine headache. However, this patient experienced headache and neck pain before the onset of neurologic symptoms. Similarly, migraine auras tend to develop gradually and symptoms typically migrate from one side of the body to the other. Lastly, they do not cause cerebrovascular accidents such as TIAs.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous mannitol is used for the management of intracranial hypertension, which may occur after ischemic stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage, both of which are complications of carotid artery dissection. Although this patient had a carotid artery dissection with ischemic neurologic symptoms (upper extremity weakness, vision loss) she does not have any signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g., papilledema, Cushing reflex).

D) CORRECT:

Treatment with antithrombotic agents (either antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants such as heparin) is indicated for carotid artery dissection after ruling out intracranial hemorrhage. Spontaneous carotid artery dissections generally have a good prognosis, but patients should be treated with an anticoagulant agent for 3–6 months and/or an antiplatelet agent for one year to reduce the risk of associated cerebrovascular accidents (such as TIA).

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombolytic therapy (e.g., alteplase) is often used to treat acute ischemic stroke, which can be a complication of carotid dissection. Although this patient had unilateral extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax, these symptoms resolved within a few minutes, suggesting a transient ischemic attack. This patient presents with ptosis and miosis without anhidrosis, indicating partial Horner syndrome, likely due to internal carotid artery dissection. Brain ischemia causes full rather than partial Horner syndrome. Furthermore, there is no evidence of ischemia on CT scan 24 hours after symptom onset.
questions.hint: Severe ipsilateral head and neck pain and partial Horner syndrome (ptosis and miosis) in combination with duplex ultrasonography findings of absent flow in the left internal carotid artery indicate a carotid artery dissection. This patient also likely experienced the complication of a transient ischemic attack (TIA), characterized by extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 36-year-old woman was in a motor vehicle crash about 3 weeks ago and suffered a significant whiplash injury. She presents with residual anterior neck pain and left supraorbital pain. Last night, she developed acute-onset right-sided face and hand weakness, as well as some difficulty producing spontaneous speech.
On examination, the patient has ptosis and a constricted pupil on the left side but no anhidrosis. She also exhibits a right-sided central facial droop with right-sided upper-extremity weakness and Broca-type aphasia.
An electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm without axis deviation. CT of the head reveals a hypodensity in the left frontal region.
Damage to which of the following structures on the left side is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Internal carotid dissection resulting from an acute trauma may initially cause only neck pain and headache, often unilateral. As the artery becomes distended, interruption of the ascending sympathetics to the eye may occur, causing a partial Horner syndrome. Anhidrosis does not occur because the sympathetic innervation of the sweat glands follows the external (not internal) carotid artery. Local distention of the internal carotid artery can also cause isolated cranial-nerve palsies. Dissection can result in emboli and stroke, often days or weeks after the trauma.

Key learning point: A patient with ipsilateral partial Horner syndrome, aphasia, and contralateral weakness following neck trauma should be evaluated for carotid dissection.

B) INCORRECT:

External carotid artery injuries do not generally lead to stroke, as this artery supplies mainly the face rather than the brain itself.

C) INCORRECT:

Damage to the jugular vein would manifest as pulsatile tinnitus, edema, or even raised intracranial pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the vertebral artery does not cause symptoms of, or reveal CT evidence of, a hemispheric stroke. Vertebral artery dissection with distal embolization may produce a posterior-circulation stroke with symptoms of brainstem or cerebellar injury, including dysarthria, dysphagia, dizziness, and diplopia.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the cavernous sinus may yield a partial Horner syndrome but would also have neurologic features specific to the sinus, such as diplopia, ocular paralysis (third, fourth, and sixth cranial-nerve palsy), and facial numbness (fifth cranial-nerve palsy).

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with a left-sided retro-orbital headache that began earlier this morning and has not responded to acetaminophen. He also reports mild neck pain on the left side and mentions that his left eye looks “funny.” He has a history of infrequent, mild, bilateral, featureless headaches but is otherwise healthy and does not smoke.
His vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, his left eyelid hangs slightly lower than the right, and his left pupil is smaller when examined in a darkened exam room; the eye is not injected. Neurologic examination, including visual acuity, is otherwise normal. Neck range of motion is normal, with no meningismus.
What is the most appropriate initial evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An episode of partial Horner syndrome with ipsilateral headache suggests a “spontaneous” extracranial carotid dissection, particularly if the patient has neck pain. Hematoma resulting in expansion of the vessel wall leads to dysfunction of the surrounding sympathetic plexus, located around the carotid bifurcation and proximal internal carotid artery.

Soft-tissue and vascular imaging of the neck is diagnostic, and it will also assess for uncommon but potentially associated arteriopathies or other dissections. CT of the brain is useful only when intracranial pathology is suspected, but CT angiography of the neck would be able to make a diagnosis of dissection similar to that of magnetic resonance angiography.

Key learning point: An episode of new, partial Horner syndrome with ipsilateral headache in an otherwise healthy patient should be assumed to be a carotid dissection, until proven otherwise.

B) INCORRECT:

Horner syndrome is always due to damage to the sympathetic nervous system, so a slit-lamp examination of the eye examining the retina, anterior chamber, and optic nerve would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

A cluster headache may manifest as a Horner episode and usually responds to 100% oxygen, but the pattern is one of brief, recurring headaches.

D) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph could reveal a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor or a widened mediastinum of an aortic dissection, but it is not helpful for an acute presentation that is inconsistent with tumor. A chest radiograph will also not identify carotid dissections.

E) INCORRECT:

CT of the brain is useful only when intracranial pathology is suspected, but CT angiography of the neck would be able to make a diagnosis of dissection similar to that of magnetic resonance angiography.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with acute-onset vertigo, ataxia, and left-sided facial numbness that began this morning. Three days ago, this patient experienced sudden, severe occipital headache after a chiropractic neck manipulation. What is the most likely initial pathophysiological process?

choices.text: Intimal tear with false lumen formation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atherosclerotic plaque rupture typically occurs in older adults with cardiovascular risk factors and is not consistent with the temporal relationship between the triggering event and this patient's specific pattern of brainstem symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasospasm alone does not account for the delayed onset of ischemic symptoms or the preceding severe occipital headache triggered by neck manipulation in a young adult.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac embolisms typically cause sudden-onset symptoms, rather than the delayed onset after neck manipulation seen in this patient, and they do not usually manifest with headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive crisis would not explain the specific posterior circulation symptoms or their temporal relationship to the mechanical trigger and preceding headache.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with vertebrobasilar insufficiency symptoms (vertigo, ataxia, ipsilateral facial numbness) following a latency period of ∼ 3 days after a sudden occipital headache triggered by chiropractic manipulation. This temporal sequence indicates vertebral artery dissection, in which the initial intimal tear creates a separation between vessel wall layers, forming a false lumen that can subsequently lead to thrombosis or stenosis, causing delayed ischemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with severe unilateral headache and neck pain that began 4 hours after a minor fall while playing basketball. He appears comfortable and his vital signs are normal. Neurological examination is normal. What is the most appropriate initial imaging study?

choices.text: Duplex ultrasonography of the neck vessels
Conventional angiography of the neck vessels

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – CT angiography of the head and neck is a first-line imaging study for suspected cervical artery dissection in neurologically intact patients. CTA has high sensitivity for both carotid and vertebral artery dissections and can identify key findings including intimal flaps, intramural hematomas, double lumen, and vessel irregularities. Both CTA and MRA are appropriate first-line choices for this indication.

B) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography has significant limitations for cervical artery dissection diagnosis as it is highly operator-dependent and frequently misses high cervical dissections. While it may show double lumen or abnormal flow patterns, it is not considered appropriate first-line imaging for this indication.

C) INCORRECT:

CT of the head without contrast is used to rule out intracranial hemorrhage in patients with acute stroke symptoms. This patient has no focal neurological deficits, and this imaging modality would not evaluate the cervical vessels where dissection occurs.

D) INCORRECT:

Conventional angiography provides the most accurate assessment of vessel stenosis but carries procedural risks including iatrogenic dissection and stroke. It is not appropriate for initial screening and is typically reserved for cases where noninvasive imaging is inconclusive despite high clinical suspicion.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain without contrast would not adequately evaluate the cervical vessels for dissection. While MRA of the head and neck is also a first-line imaging option, standard brain MRI without contrast lacks the vascular detail needed to diagnose cervical artery dissection.
